title: WhatsApp leakage allows device fingerprinting via multi-device protocol
executive_summary: Researchers have identified that WhatsApp’s multi-device encryption implementation inadvertently leaks metadata that can be used to identify the operating system of users’ devices.
This device fingerprinting information can aid attackers in tailoring exploits or malware to specific platforms without direct user interaction.
what_happened: WhatsApp’s multi-device feature creates separate encrypted sessions for each device, generating unique encryption keys per device.
Differences in device key identifiers (e.g., Signed Pre-Key and One-Time Pre-Key patterns) let attackers distinguish operating systems like Android and iOS.
Attackers can passively query WhatsApp servers for these session keys to infer device types without alerting users.
Meta has partially addressed this issue by randomizing some key assignment values, but other distinguishable identifiers remain.
who_is_affected: Organizations relying on WhatsApp for secure communications.
Security teams concerned about targeted attacks based on device type.
attack_flow: Attacker identifies a target’s WhatsApp account.
Attacker queries session key identifiers via the multi-device protocol.
Extracted metadata reveals the device operating system.
Attacker uses that information to choose platform-specific exploits or payloads.
business_impact: Increased risk of targeted malware delivery customized for specific devices.
Potential reconnaissance advantage for advanced persistent threats.
Undermining of perceived privacy guarantees of end-to-end messaging.
risk_reason: Even encrypted messaging protocols can inadvertently leak metadata that facilitates device classification, which attackers can use to tailor higher-impact attacks without user interaction.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Assuming end-to-end encryption covers all metadata privacy.
Not monitoring protocol features that reveal side-channel indicators.
Delays in assigning public vulnerability tracking (e.g., CVEs) for metadata issues.

immediate: Review mobile platform security posture and avoid relying solely on metadata guarantees.
Encourage users to limit linked devices where feasible.
short_term: Monitor for unusual or targeted exploit attempts informed by device type.
Engage with vendor advisories to understand ongoing fixes.
long_term: Advocate for transparent vendor disclosure and CVE tracking of metadata privacy issues.
Assess use of additional privacy-strengthening measures (e.g., SIM-binding, stronger session isolation).

what_this_does_not_mean: WhatsApp encryption is broken — the core message encryption remains secure.
Every WhatsApp user is actively at risk of compromise — the issue is metadata leakage, not direct code execution.

signs: Unusual targeted payload attempts based on known device types.
Unexpected probing of multi-device session features.
alerts: Detection of reconnaissance activity tied to messaging protocols.
Unusual access patterns to WhatsApp session metadata.
